Research Paper Distinctive pathways of single-atom and nanoparticle sites over Co-based catalysts for furfuryl alcohol hydrogenation Fan Xue Writing – original draft Validation Methodology Investigation Shangpu Zhuang Writing – original draft Software Resources Jingyue Bi Writing – review & editing Zhaoyang Fei Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Xu Qiao Funding acquisition ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, Jiangsu 211816, PR China State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University Nanjing Jiangsu 211816 PR China State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, Jiangsu 211816, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The targeted transformation of biomass resources into premium chemicals and biofuels stands out as a highly promising approach to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions and curb environmental pollution caused by excessive use of fossil fuels. The catalysts with diverse active sites are crucial to determine the products distribution of furan-containing bio-based feedstocks hydrogenation. Herein, Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts have been successfully prepared and demonstrated distinct reaction pathways in the selective hydrogenation of furfuryl alcohol (FOL). Notably, the Co1/NC catalyst showed 11.8 % FOL conversion within 1 h and both furan ring (C = C) and the C–OH could be hydrogenated over CoN4 sites. In contrast, the Co nanoparticles were more inclined to facilitate the activation and cleavage of C–OH bond in FOL with 92.2 % selectivity of 2-methylfuran and its derivatives over CoNPs/NC catalyst. Although the temperature, H2 pressure and solvents can affect products distribution, their impact differences also depended on the nature of the active sites. This work underscores the importance of a thorough understanding about the structure–activity relationship, which is crucial to systematic design suitable catalysts with tailored active sites for specific catalytic reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Furfuryl alcohol Hydrogenation Single atom catalysts Nanoparticles Cobalt Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Currently, the severe reliance on the consumption of fossil fuel supply has triggered significant environmental, political, and economic issues [1]. To advance the sustainable exploitation of the plentiful energetic biomass, the process of converting biomass and fundamental chemical intermediates into more valuable products has garnered considerable interest. This strategy is seen as a promising response to the pressing requirement for substitutes to conventional fossil resources [2]. Furfuryl alcohol (FOL), as one of the most extensively studied lignocellulose derivatives, emerges as a critical and cost-effective bio-derived chemical building block that can be refined into a diverse array of premium fuels and intricate chemicals through hydrogenation techniques [3,4]. Particularly, FOL has excellent versatility in the production of various high-value fine chemicals, such as 2-methylfuran (2-MF), 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MTHF), 1-pentanol (1-PO), 2-pentanol (2-PO), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) and others [5,6]. Nevertheless, various hydrogenation routes compete fiercely with the ring opening of FOL, leading to different main products [7] Besides, the opening of furan ring in THFA requires relatively strict reaction conditions (H2 pressure 6 ∼ 8 MPa) [8]. Recently, substantial research work has been focused to develop the catalysts and explore the FOL hydrogenation reaction pathways. As is known to all, the hydrogenation of furfuryl alcohol involves a complex interplay of reduction reactions, catalyst selectivity, and potential side reactions, all of which determine the overall yield and the desired products selectivity [9]. The selectivity and activity of the catalyst are crucial in determining product distribution [10]. The catalysts with specific active sites can favor the hydrogenation of particular chemical bonds, such as the furan ring and carbonyl (C=O) groups. Due to the various reaction pathways involved in FOL hydrogenation, it is difficult to rationally fabricate active sites on the catalysts and balance reaction parameters such as temperature, pressure, and solvent to direct FOL to follow specific reaction pathways, thereby achieving high selectivity for the target products [5]. Therefore, it is essential to investigate the impact of catalyst active sites on the hydrogenation pathway of FOL to achieve targeted transformations. Typically, traditional nanoparticles (NPs) feature a diverse array of active sites, allowing reactants or intermediates to adsorb and undergo reactions based on the specific thermodynamic and kinetic preferences of each individual site. For example, it has been proved that the noble nanoparticles catalyst, could realize the high yield of 1,5-pentanediol (1,5-PEO) (50 ∼ 70 %) through THFA reaction route during the hydrogenation of FOL [1,11–16. Distinct from conventional metal nanoparticles (NPs) catalysts, the single atom catalysts (SACs) have gained more attention owing to the maximized exposure of active sites, an exceptionally even distribution of atoms and unsaturated coordination configuration [17–22]. Specifically, it has been proved that Co-based single atoms catalysts could effectively improve the hydrogenation of biomass and its derivatives [23–25]. Notably, the product distribution of FOL hydrogenation varies significantly between single atom and nanoparticle sites, which can be attributed to the distinct adsorption-catalysis mechanisms facilitated by the unique active sites of each catalyst type [26,27. These observations inspire further investigation into the relationship between the active site coordination structure and activity at the atomic scale. The catalysts (including SACs and NPs catalysts) derived from zeolite imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are a burgeoning research field that has garnered significant interest due to their remarkable catalytic performance in various catalytic processes, such as electrocatalysis [28], photocatalysis [29] and thermo-catalysis [30]. ZIFs constructed by the regular interconnection of metal ions or clusters with organic linkers to form a 3D porous skeleton, have proven to be ideal self-sacrificial templates for designing catalysts with specific active sites, especially single atom catalysts, through their high-temperature pyrolysis under an inert atmosphere [31] Following pyrolysis, these metal atoms are securely immobilized onto the N-modified carbon matrix, creating M–Nx configurations [32]. SACs derived from ZIFs exhibit an outstanding pore network, fully exposing M–Nx active sites and efficiently facilitating the diffusion of reactants, thereby augmenting the overall catalytic effectiveness [33]. Furthermore, by modifying the preparation conditions, nanoparticle catalysts derived from ZIFs can also be synthesized to demonstrate excellent activity. These active sites could also catalyze biomass and its derivatives into high valued fine chemicals [34]. The diverse coordination geometries can induce changes in the electronic configurations at the metal active sites, which in turn influence the adsorption of reactants or products, thereby affecting catalytic efficiency and selectivity [35] In this work, the Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts were fabricated through the thermal decomposition of Co-ZIF precursors. The obtained Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts were applied into FOL hydrogenation to investigate the influence of CoN4 sites and Co nanoparticles active sites on the reaction pathways. In addition, the study investigated the sensitivity of various active sites to the changes in reaction temperature and pressure. The roles of solvents including methanol, ethanol and isopropanol were investigated. Our findings here provide a profound exploration of the disparities between M–Nx active sites and metal nanoparticles in the biomass transformation process at the atomic scale, which is crucial to fabricate the suitable catalysts with tailored sites for desired products. 2 Experimental section The information of the materials and instruments required is provided in the supporting information. 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts Synthesis of ZIF-8. Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (1,6 g) and 2-methylimidazole (4 g) were both dissolved in methanol. Subsequently, the above solution was sonicated for 30 min and aged at room temperature (RT) for 24 h. Then the solid obtained from centrifugation of the solution was washed with methanol for several times. Finally, the solid product was dried at 60 °C and named as ZIF-8. Synthesis of Cobalt doped into ZIF-8 precursors (Co-ZIF). The Co-ZIF precursor was synthesized using a methodology previously reported in the literature [36] 1.6 g Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, 40 mg of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 2-methylimidazole were dissolved in 80 mL methanol and then was ultrasonicated for 30 min. Subsequently, the solution was aged at RT for 24 h. The solid was separated from the solvent after aging and then was washed with methanol for several times. The cleaned product was then dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Finally, the synthetic purple sample was designated as Co-ZIF. Preparation of NC and Co supported by nitrogen doped carbon catalysts. The ZIF-8 and Co-ZIF powder was pyrolyzed in a tube furnace at 900 °C for 3 h under flowing nitrogen gas with a heating rate of 5 °C⋅min−1. The obtained black powder was named as NC and Co1/NC catalysts, respectively. When the Co-ZIF powder was pyrolyzed in a tube furnace at 800 °C for 3 h, the CoNPs/NC catalyst was achieved. The process diagram of catalyst preparation mechanism is shown in Scheme 1 . When 20 mg and 30 mg of Co(NO3)2·6H2O were employed, the resulting products were designated as Co1/NC-1 and Co1/NC-2, respectively. 2.2 Catalysts evaluation The FOL hydrogenation reaction was carried out in a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave that was fitted with a mechanical agitator under the targeted temperature (120 ∼ 150 °C). The autoclave was purged ten times with high-purity H2 to eliminate the air inside, after which it was charged with a specific H2 pressure. The reaction was then allowed to proceed for a certain amount of time (0 ∼ 5 h). In each test, 25 mg catalyst, 125 mg FOL and 10 mL ethanol were used during the reaction. The separated liquid samples were analyzed by Agilent 7890A gas chromatography. The FOL conversion and the products selectivity were calculated using the following equation: (1.1) Conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − Moles of FOL after reaction Initial moles of FOL ) × 100 % (1.2) Selectivity ( % ) = Moles of products Initial moles of FOL × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Design and structural characterizations The cobalt doped ZIF-8 precursors (Co-ZIF) were employed to synthesize Co-based catalysts, which were subsequently pyrolyzed under a nitrogen atmosphere to prepare cobalt catalysts supported on nitrogen-doped carbon (Scheme. 1). Fig. S1 showed the XRD results of the ZIF-8 and Co-ZIF precursor. It can be found the sharp and well-defined peaks in the Co-ZIF precursor, which closely resemble those of the original ZIF-8 structure. Notably, the main peak of Co-ZIF precursor shifted slightly to a smaller angle compared with the pristine ZIF-8, indicating that the Co2+ ions partially substituted the Zn2+ ions [37]. Additionally, the SEM images, as shown in Fig. S2, indicated that the morphology of Co-ZIF precursor is very similar to that of the undoped original ZIF-8. However, following cobalt doping, it can be found that the size of Co-ZIF particles (∼ 250 nm) was larger than that of ZIF-8 (∼ 150 nm). All the results indicated that the preparation of Co-ZIF precursor is successful. Besides, the SEM images of NC, Co1/NC, and CoNPs/NC catalysts obtained after heat treatment are displayed in Fig. S3. Obviously, the NC, Co1/NC, and CoNPs/NC catalysts all still maintained the dodecahedron morphology well and the particles size were similar to the corresponding precursors, proving that the heat treatment did not affect the structure. To further elucidate the morphology of the synthesized catalysts, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was employed to visualize the cobalt species within Co1/NC (Fig. 1 a) and CoNPs/NC catalysts (Fig. 1 d). The results revealed the absence of detectable metal particles or clusters in the Co1/NC catalyst, suggesting a high degree of cobalt dispersion. Furthermore, the HRTEM images of the Co1/NC catalyst displayed a highly disorganized amorphous carbon matrix, which points to a lack of crystallinity and the existence of a disordered carbon structure. In contrast, the CoNPs/NC catalyst featured cobalt nanoparticles, ranging from 20 to 40 nm in diameter, distributed across the surface. In order to observe the cobalt species distribution of the Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts in more detail, the high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) was taken. Only the single cobalt atoms defined by yellow circles are uniformly dispersed on the surface of the Co1/NC catalyst (Fig. 1 b). This contrasted with the CoNPs/NC catalyst, where in addition to dispersed individual cobalt atoms, red-circled cobalt nanoparticles, formed from the aggregation of cobalt atoms, were also evident, indicating a mixed-phase catalyst with both single atoms and nanoparticles (Fig. 1 e) .Additionally, an interplanar spacing of 0.204 nm was identified, which corresponds to the (111) plane of cobalt. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping confirmed the uniform distribution of carbon, nitrogen, and cobalt atoms throughout the Co1/NC catalyst, (Fig. 1 c) while the CoNPs/NC catalyst once again showed the presence of both single cobalt atoms and nanoparticles (Fig. 1 f). The XRD patterns shown in Fig. 2 a were acquired for the NC, Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts. These patterns revealed that all catalysts exhibited two broad peaks at approximately 2θ ≈ 25 ° and 44 °, which corresponded to the diffraction of carbon. This observation confirms the successful synthesis of the nitrogen-doped carbon support. Besides, the peaks of metallic Co, Co oxides or CoxC was absent over the Co1/NC catalyst, indicating the possibility of highly dispersed surface cobalt atoms [38]. In the CoNPs/NC catalyst, three distinct peaks corresponding to the (111), (200) and (220) lattice planes of metal Co were observed at approximately 44, 52 and 76 °, respectively [39]. These peaks indicated the presence of cobalt nanoparticles within the CoNPs/NC catalyst. Raman spectroscopy serves as a powerful method for investigating the defect degree in carbon materials, typically assessed through the ratio of the D band at 1345 cm−1 and the G band at 1575 cm−1 (ID/IG) [40]. As depicted in Fig. 2 b, the ID/IG value for the Co1/NC catalyst (1.45) was observed to be greater than that of the CoNPs/NC catalyst (1.17), was attributed to the higher density of defects in Co1/NC catalyst. These defects can contribute to the enhanced catalytic activity by providing more active sites for chemical reactions. The N2 adsorption/desorption results of the precursors were shown in Fig. S4 and the ZIF-8 and Co-ZIF precursors both displayed type I isotherms, indicating the predominantly microporous structure. The surface area of Co-ZIF precursors was 1372 m2⋅g−1. However, the BET surface area of Co1/NC catalyst was 928 m2⋅g−1, exceeds that of the CoNPs/NC catalyst (800 m2⋅g−1), (Table 1 ) which can be inferred that the pores on the surface of the catalysts may be blocked by the generated NPs. The higher ID/IG value and BET surface area of Co1/NC catalyst were beneficial to expose more active sites and improve the accessibility between reactants and active sites. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis is used to further investigate the electronic structures of Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts. The survey scanning spectra shown in confirmed the presence of Co, C, N, and O in both the Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts, indicating the co-existence of these elements. (Fig. S5) The O 1 s XPS spectra of Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts, obtained above 530 eV, could be deconvoluted into two peaks in Fig. 2 c. These peaks, located at 531.7 eV and 532.5 eV, correspond to C–O and N–O bonds, respectively, which suggests the absence of surface cobalt oxide. For the C 1 s spectrum of these catalysts, the peak could be deconvoluted into three distinct peaks at 284.8 eV (C–C), 285.8 eV (C–N), and 287.2 eV (O–C=N), as illustrated in Fig. 2 d. The high-resolution N 1 s spectra for the Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts disclosed the presence of four types of N environments, namely pyridinic–N (398.3 eV), Co–Nx (398.9 eV), pyrrolic–N (399.9 eV), and graphitic–N (401.1 eV) (Fig. 2 e) [41]. The existence of Co–Nx peaks indicates the effective incorporation of cobalt into the porous carbon matrixes in the catalysts. Indeed, the presence of metal–Nx sites has been widely reported to induce electron modulation, which can fine-tune the chemical activity of carbon-based catalysts, thereby inhibiting the severe aggregation of Co nanoparticles throughout the reaction process [42,43]. According to the percentage of peaks area (Table 1), the Co–Nx content in Co1/NC catalyst (30.0 %) was larger than that of CoNPs/NC catalyst (27.0 %), indicating a decrease in the amount of single atom sites and a tendency for cobalt atoms to aggregate on the CoNPs/NC catalyst. The high-resolution Co 2p spectra of Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts primarily consisted of Co2+, Co3+ species and their satellite peaks. (Fig. 2 f) [44]. Notably, an extra peak attributed to Co0 species was observed in the Co 2p spectrum of the CoNPs/NC catalyst, which confirms the presence of Co nanoparticles. The X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) measurements were used to further investigate the chemical states and geometrical configuration of the Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts. Fig. 3 a displayed the Co K-edge XANES spectrum for the Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts, along with the standard samples used as references. The Co K-edge near edge spectra of the Co1/NC catalyst was between the Co(II) and Co(III) states. This result was also observed in the Co 2p spectra. The Fourier transform of the extended X-ray absorption fine structure spectrum (FT-EXAFS) showed that the Co1/NC catalyst exhibited a prominent peak at 1.4 Å, which was attributed to the Co–N first coordination shell, indicating that cobalt atoms were distributed as single atoms. (Fig. 3 b). In contrast, two peaks were observed at 1.4 Å and 2.2 Å over the CoNPs/NC catalyst, representing to Co–N and Co–Co bond, respectively [45]. This suggested the presence of both single cobalt atoms and Co nanoparticles in the CoNPs/NC catalyst. Moreover, to gain a clearer understanding of the coordination environment of cobalt species in the Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts, the FT-EXAFS spectra could be used to quantify the specific structure of the Co–Nx sites. (Fig. 3 c and Table 2 ). For the Co1/NC catalyst, the optimized fitting outcomes indicated that the length of Co–N bond was 1.8 Å and the average coordination number (CN) of cobalt atom was 4, confirming the formation of CoN4 sites within the Co1/NC catalyst (Fig. 3 c the inset). Nevertheless, for the CoNPs/NC catalyst, in addition to the CoN4 structure, the results of FT-EXAFS also revealed the presence of Co–Co bonds with a length of 2.8 Å. (Fig. 3 d). This finding provides further evidence for the simultaneous existing of single cobalt atoms and cobalt nanoparticles within the catalyst. In addition, the wavelet transform (WT) analysis was conducted to confirm the backscattered atoms around the active sites. The WT plot of Co1/NC catalyst (Fig. 3 e) displays the intensity maxima that correlate with the Co–N bond, with a corresponding k value of approximately 4.2 Å−1. The WT analysis of CoNPs/NC catalyst (Fig. 3 f) one more indicated the coexistence of Co single atoms and nanoparticles, consistent with the EXAFS fitting parameters. As illustrated in Fig. 4 , the acidic properties of the Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts were investigated by NH3-TPD. A distinct peak at 101 °C was observed for CoNPs/NC catalyst, corresponding to weak acidity [46]. The first peak for Co1/NC catalyst was at a slightly higher temperature of 107 °C, with a reduced peak intensity compared with CoNPs/NC catalyst. Furthermore, both catalysts displayed strong acidity peaks, with the CoNPs/NC catalyst showing a peak at 662 °C and the Co1/NC catalyst at 709 °C. Notably, the strong acidity peak intensity of CoNPs/NC catalyst was higher than that of Co1/NC catalyst. The results have indicated that the different active sites structure could influence the acidity of the catalyst and the existence of NPs would improve the amount of the acid sites, which played a significant role in the hydrogenolysis of C–OH. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the catalysts The ZIFs derived cobalt-based catalysts were employed to evaluate the hydrogenation of FOL, and the catalytic performance of Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts was summarized in Table 3 . In the absence of a catalyst, the reaction exhibited negligible FOL conversion. Upon introduction of the NC catalyst, a modest FOL conversion of 1.2 % was achieved. Subsequent experiments employing catalysts with varying Co content revealed a significant enhancement in catalytic performance. Specifically, the FOL conversion demonstrated a progressive increase from 8.1 % to 11.8 % corresponding to the elevated Co content in the catalysts. These results clearly indicate that the incorporation of Co active sites plays a pivotal role in facilitating the reaction, serving as a crucial determinant of catalytic efficiency. The FOL conversion was 11.8 % within 1 h under 3 MPa H2 pressure and 120 °C over the Co1/NC catalyst, and the selectivity of the main products 2-MF and its derivatives (2-Methyltetrahydrofuran) could achieve 67.4 %. Additionally, the selectivity for THFA was 24.6 %. It can be summarized that both furan ring (C=C) and the C–OH are hydrogenated over CoN4 sites. In comparison, the CoNPs/NC catalyst resulted in a lower FOL conversion (4.5 %), which is less effective than that of the Co1/NC catalyst. The selectivity for 2-MF and its derivatives was 92.2 %, yet its ability to activate C=C bonds was limited, as evidenced by the low THFA selectivity of 3.5 %. Therefore, it can be speculated that the CoN4 sites and the Co nanoparticles played different roles during the FOL hydrogenation reaction. Subsequently, the reaction rate (r, mmolFOL·mmolCo −1·h−1) was measured of FOL during the initial stage (within 1 h) over Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts (Table 3). The Co1/NC catalyst gave initial reaction rate of 15.9 mmolFOL·mmolCo −1·h−1, higher than that of CoNPs/NC catalyst (3.8 mmolFOL·mmolCo −1·h−1). It is inferred that the Co1/NC catalyst demonstrated superior activity, while Co nanoparticles may preferentially facilitate the hydrogenolysis of C–OH groups, resulting in the generation of 2-MF and its derivatives. Based on the results of NH3-TPD, the CoNPs/NC catalyst had more acidic sites, making them more favorable for the hydrogenation hydrolysis of C–OH. Besides, Table. S1 showed the reported literature and it can be found that the TOF value of Co1/NC catalyst have certain comparability [3,47–52] and the ring-opening reactions do not occur under lower hydrogen pressure. Therefore, it can be concluded that the single atom catalysts could improve the atomic utilization efficiency. In order to study the FOL hydrogenation process in detail, the evolution of products over time was tracked for both the Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts under 3 MPa H2 pressure and 120 °C. As shown in Fig. 5 a, the conversion of FOL increased to 67.8 % with time extended to 5 h over Co1/NC catalyst. In a parallel manner, the conversion of FOL increased to 39.5 % with time extended to 5 h over CoNPs/NC catalyst (Fig. 5 b), but lower than that of the conversion of FOL over Co1/NC catalyst. The results further indicated that the activity of Co1/NC catalyst is higher than that of CoNPs/NC catalyst, which may be due to the highly dispersed CoN4 sites, improving the accessibility between active sites and reactant molecules. Besides, the 2-MF and its derivatives are still the main products over Co1/NC catalyst and the selectivity of them was 59.9 % at 5 h. The selectivity of THFA gradually increased to 27.2 %. The results indicated the hydrogenolysis of C–OH was the main route over the CoN4 sites, but the CoN4 sites may experience the hydrogenation of the C=C bond from the furan ring to generate THFA. Similarly, the 2-MF and its derivatives were also the main product when the CoNPs/NC catalyst was used as the catalyst, and even higher than that of Co1/NC catalyst. This result further confirmed that Co nanoparticles were more inclined towards the reaction pathway of 2-MF, which may be due to that the amount of the acid sites of CoNPs/NC catalyst was higher than that of Co1/NC catalyst. Furthermore, the catalytic performance of Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts in the catalytic FOL hydrogenation was evaluated at different reaction temperature, H2 pressure and solvent. Under different reaction conditions, the selectivity of major products was both different over Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . For the Co1/NC catalyst (Fig. 6 a), elevating the reaction temperature from 120 °C to 150 °C resulted in a significant enhancement of FOL conversion from 11.8 % to 27.5 %. The product distribution exhibited a complex temperature dependence. The selectivity of 2-MF and its derivatives initially decreased to 24.6 %, followed by an increase to 61.0 %. Concurrently, the selectivity of n-PO (1-pentanol and 2-pentanol) showed an inverse correlation with 2-MF selectivity, while THFA selectivity remained relatively stable within the range of 24.6 % to 31.4 %. This temperature-dependent product distribution can be attributed to the alterations in the adsorption geometry of reactants and intermediates, as previously demonstrated in literature [53]. Besides, the increased temperature would enhance molecular activation energy or accelerate reaction rate. Comparatively, when the temperature increased from 120 °C to 150 °C, the conversion of FOL increased from 4.5 % to 12.7 % over CoNPs/NC catalyst (Fig. 6 b). The selectivity of 2-MF and its derivatives decreased from 92.2 % to 64.7 %, accompanied by THFA selectivity increased to 20.3 %. Besides, higher temperature would be beneficial to the furan ring (C=C) hydrogenation to produce THFA over CoN4 sites and Co nanoparticles. However, compared to CoN4 sites, Co NPs still tend to hydrogenate C-OH groups. The effect of H2 pressure on FOL hydrogenation was evaluated. Obviously, the conversion of FOL was decreased significantly from 11.8 % to 1.6 % over Co1/NC catalyst as the pressure decreased from 3 MPa to 1 MPa (Fig. 6 c). When the H2 pressure decreased to 1 MPa, the THFA became the main product and the selectivity was 44.2 %. When the H2 pressure decreased to 1 MPa, the selectivity of 2-MF and its derivatives decreased to 60.6 % over CoNPs/NC catalyst (Fig. 6 d) and THFA selectivity was increased to 27.7 %. The n-PO selectivity was both relatively stable over Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts. These findings indicate that variations in H2 pressure do not significantly affect the furan ring opening, regardless of whether the catalyst features single-atom or nanoparticle active sites. It can be observed that the 2-MF and its derivatives selectivity of CoNPs/NC catalyst was always higher than that of Co1/NC catalyst, indicating Co NPs still tend to hydrogenate C-OH groups. To investigate the influence of solvent on the catalytic performance, the hydrogenation of FOL over the Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts was conducted in various solvents. As depicted in Fig. 6 e, upon employing methanol as the solvent, THFA emerged as the predominant product in both Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts, indicating that the proton availability in methanol is conducive to the hydrogenation saturation of the furan ring. The FOL conversion in methanol was lower than those of in ethanol. The conversion of FOL in isopropanol was about 9.0 %, just slightly lower than that in ethanol and primarily yielded 2-MF and its derivatives as the main products over Co1/NC catalyst. While THFA became the main products in isopropanol over the CoNPs/NC catalyst, with the FOL conversion was 5.6 %. Therefore, it can be concluded that the effect of solvents on activity and product distribution is also strongly influenced by the structure of the active sites. These findings provide valuable mechanistic insights into the temperature-, pressure-, and solvent-dependent catalytic behaviors of both atomically dispersed and nanoparticle-based cobalt catalysts. Importantly, the reaction pathways and products distributions are predominantly governed by the specific configuration of the active sites, as illustrated in the proposed reaction mechanism depicted in Fig. 7 . It can be confirmed that the CoNPs/NC catalyst possesses a higher density of acidic sites, which predominantly facilitates the hydrogenation of C–OH bond under most reaction conditions. Under varying temperature and pressure conditions, the Co NPs sites consistently exhibit a stronger preference for the 2-MF reaction pathway. Nevertheless, the elevated temperatures or reduced pressure conditions enhance THFA selectivity for both Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalyst. Regardless of variations in temperature and pressure, the THFA selectivity of Co1/NC catalyst consistently surpassed that of the CoNPs/NC catalyst. 4 Conclusion In summary, the Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts were successfully synthesized via the direct thermal decomposition of Co-ZIF precursor, exhibiting distinct reaction pathways during the selective hydrogenation of FOL under identical reaction conditions. From the XPS and XANES results, it has been discovered that Co atoms, which are atomically dispersed, have been effectively immobilized by coordinating with four N atoms over Co1/NC catalyst, while the Co NPs and CoN4 sites co-existed over CoNPs/NC catalyst. The influence of catalyst structure on the FOL hydrogenation and the products distributions was studied systematically. Remarkably, the CoN4 sites demonstrated exceptional activity in FOL hydrogenation, facilitating the hydrogenation of both the furan ring (C=C) and the C–OH group. In contrast, the Co nanoparticles were more inclined to the 2-MF reaction pathway. Although the temperature, pressure and solvent can affect catalytic behavior, the reaction pathway and products distribution are fundamentally controlled by the specific configuration of the active site. This study emphasizes the effect of the catalyst structure on the products distributions, which is crucial for guiding the logically design of specific catalyst active sites to achieve directional transformation of biomass and its derived compounds. coredata.dc:description: The targeted transformation of biomass resources into premium chemicals and biofuels stands out as a highly promising approach to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions and curb environmental pollution caused by excessive use of fossil fuels. The catalysts with diverse active sites are crucial to determine the products distribution of furan-containing bio-based feedstocks hydrogenation. Herein, Co1/NC and CoNPs/NC catalysts have been successfully prepared and demonstrated distinct reaction pathways in the selective hydrogenation of furfuryl alcohol (FOL). Notably, the Co1/NC catalyst showed 11.8 % FOL conversion within 1 h and both furan ring (C = C) and the C–OH could be hydrogenated over CoN4 sites. In contrast, the Co nanoparticles were more inclined to facilitate the activation and cleavage of C–OH bond in FOL with 92.2 % selectivity of 2-methylfuran and its derivatives over CoNPs/NC catalyst. Although the temperature, H2 pressure and solvents can affect products distribution, their impact differences also depended on the nature of the active sites. This work underscores the importance of a thorough understanding about the structure–activity relationship, which is crucial to systematic design suitable catalysts with tailored active sites for specific catalytic reactions.

coredata.dc:title: Distinctive pathways of single-atom and nanoparticle sites over Co-based catalysts for furfuryl alcohol hydrogenation
